author: Sabec74

description.text:
This is an updated Velleman k8200 clip to hold their glass panel on the heated bed. The clips that Velleman provide stls for are square in shape and the tolerances are off so they don't provide any pressure on the glass to hold it down. These are the same basic size (a little longer on top) and I've included the source file if you want to modify them to be shorter.  
These clips provide enough tension to hold the glass in place while printing. I printed these with 100% infill and they've been holding their shape/tension quite well.

title: Trombone: Fully Functioning
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
FINALLY! A FULLY FUNCTIONING TROMBONE!!!!! All the items fit into each other like a regular trombone. It even uses a MOUTHPIECE! The trombone is smaller than most and the mouthpiece is smaller too!
Thanks to Gernreich who created a new mouthpiece and built-in support for the inner-slide that made printing of the Trombone: Fully Functioning possible.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.15 or below

Infill:

50% (100% Recommended)

Notes: It is reccomended to print all of the trombone pieces seperatly. Print mouthpiece with 10 shells or higer at at least 50% infill for maximum performance (100% infill).

Inner-Slide Smoothing and Lubricating To make the Trombone: Fully Functioning's sliding more efficient, it is recommended to smooth out the inner-slide and add slide lubricant. To smooth the inner-slide move the inner-slide and the outer-slide back and fourth until smooth or use sand paper careful. For lubricating, Trombone slide oil or vale oil will work best.

UPDATE The Trombone: Fully Functioning is fully operational. If all of the pieces are printed at the recommended layers, the trombone will work as you can see in the makes of the Trombone: Fully Functioning. In addition, I am accepting any comments about the Trombone: Fully Functioning and will take to consideration any additions individuals may have on the trombone.

Special Thanks to Gernreich Special thanks to Gernreich who made the Trombone: Fully Functioning complete with supports built into designs for the inner slide and a new design for the mouthpiece. If you want to find more about Gernreich, his designs, makes, and likes; you can visit: http://www.thingiverse.com/Gernreich/about

Garbage bag holder for under the sink/in utility cabinet.  I attached them using 3M Command Strips (double-sided mounting tape), but included some screw holes, if you prefer.

Keeps a water bowl topped up. You provide the bowl and the water bottle. You must drill out the cap. See instructions. There are a few of these water bowl things on Thingiverse. Most of them print the bowl along with the bottle holder. I wanted one that would clip to the side of the bowl I already have. I also decided to incorporate the bottle's own cap instead of printing a thread. STEP and Fusion 360 files provided if you want to vary the dimensions. Updated: version 2 files have a hook on the lip to stabilize from side to side nudges, if your bowl has a flange like mine. The model was also redrawn to simplify the design history and put more dimensions in parameterized sketches. Updated: v3 cap holder has an extended back wall to provide a larger contact patch when printing in two parts. Use with the v2 tub. Single print model should not have a delamination issue. Updated: v4 replaces the open tub with useless side vents with a solid holder with a full hole to provide more surface area for the cap to grip. If you have a Dremel, check out my bottle cap hole drilling jig to adapt your bottle cap.

Take the water bottle cap and drill out the top. You want a big an opening as possible. My largest drill bit wasn't big enough, so I ended up filling it larger. You can tell it is big enough when water glugs out of the bottle when held upside down without jostling or squeezing.  
If your bottle cap is slightly under 31mm in diameter, you can glue it into position at the outside end of the mount. I used a generous amount of two part epoxy around half the cap and part way around the top. You will want to use an adhesive that can stand up to the shear forces of opening and closing the cap.  
There are three STLs provided, one which is the whole part, and two which are the bracket arm and the mount as separate parts for printing separately without support, which you can glue together using IPS Weld-On #4 (for PLA or ABS), acetone (ABS only), or superglue. Print the arm with one side down, and the mount with the bottom down.

comments.text:
I used openscad to make this one some months ago but I had trouble with sealing it.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:483764
I couldn't use vase mode because the circumference is non continuous at the lip.
A redesign would allow me to do that but I think using an already sealed pet-g bottle for the airlock is the better way. If you hunt for a bottle top thread then that would simplify your bottle socket, then perhaps a tripod arrangement with one leg being a spot and the vertex being the bottle socket? That would allow flexibility in the drinking dish though I would prefer only a small lapping dish for drinking from to minimize evaporative surface area.
comments.author: fluidity

comments.text: I am aware of laird's PCO-1881 thread OpenSCAD model (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:157541) which I considered using, but I figured why not use the perfect bottle thread someone has injection molded for me that came with the bottle? Perhaps I will still try that, and do an OpenSCAD model.
comments.author: fluidity

comments.text:
Very nifty.
I was thinking a while ago about making a bowl with a soda drink bottle socket to screw it in and get the same effect but given the right existing bowl, your solution uses less plastic. It does look a bit fragile though, I cant see how it's protected from tipping over if bumped?
comments.author: fluidity

comments.text: I've put a bottom lip on the anchor hook, to stabilize it better on bowls with flanges like mine. I've also simplified the Fusion 360 design history so it should be easier to modify, if you use Fusion 360.
comments.author: fluidity

comments.text: Bumped front and back is no problem. Lateral stability does turn out to be an issue, very astute. I've "solved" it for now with some tape. I am going to try extending the clip further around the bowl, or introducing a hook along the bottom of the clip to engage the bowl flange. The weight of the bottle pulls the top of the clip forward, so putting in enough clearance for the hook to get over the flange should not be a problem.

title: Milwaukee M12 Cordless Flashlight P60 "Drop In" LED module adapter

description.text:
Hacks-all your Milwaukee M12 Cordless Flashlight with an LED "drop in" module. Print two adapters and sandwich the light module in the middle. Unsolder the old bulb holder and solder in the drop in module. Double check the polarity. Also, beware some drop in modules do not support 12-13V. These old incandescent bulb flashlights are on clearance at home depot for $15 or so. http://www.homedepot.com/p/Milwaukee-M12-12-Volt-Battery-Xenon-Work-Light-49-24-0145/202043578 Below is an example "drop in" module.
http://www.amazon.com/TUOFENG%C2%AE-Flashlight-Bulb-Upgrade-Drop/dp/B0058E8HYE/ref=pd_cp_hi_0 The second set has tighter tolerances.

description.text:

author: lightsey67

description.text:
Admit it ! You've always wanted a shark fin for your dachshund !  
Or maybe that's just me. Now, with 3D printing, you can have one.  
Print it and paint it. Easy.

• The main fin was designed from a picture of a shark fin using www.smoothie-3d.com and output to an STL file.
  • The STL file was scaled 1000 times in Slic3r, and a few millimetres shaved from the bottom to provide a flat base and the STL saved.
  • This STL file was then modified in 123D Design to add in the holes for the straps, saved as an STL again, then sliced in Slic3r with .2mm thickness and 10% fill and output to gcode, to make it very light when printed.

author: MobyDisk

description.text: This is a template to help you join two pieces of wood with 3/8 inch dowels. If you use the entire template, the joint will have 5 dowels and 3 screws, which will be very strong. You don't need a drill press, just a power drill and a 3/8" drill bit. This print requires support, unless you have a heated bed and can print the large flat base without curling (otherwise the template is not very accurate). I print at Low Quality on a Makerbot Replicator 2, with 30% infill density, for stiffness. To use the part, clamp the pieces you want to join together, and then clamp the template on top (you could try to drill the pieces separately, but I think doing both at once works better). Now drill all the way through the top piece and down into the second. You will need to figure out the right depth and mark your 3/8" drill bit. Then take the guide off, put the dowels in the lower piece, and slide the upper piece down on the dowels. Initially the holes in the guide will be a bit small, so you will drill out a bit of plastic. And if your drill is a bit wobbly (mine is) then the guide might deform a little bit as you are drilling. If you feel like it is too loose, crank up the infill density. The guide also has three 1/8" holes, for drilling screw pilot holes. You can also use these holes to re-position the guide if you need to, just stick a 1/8" bit in each hole and slide the guide down them. I used glue on the dowels and between the pieces. If you wanted to be able to disassemble, the screws are probably enough to hold it together. If you skip the screws, you can plug the holes and the result will look relatively seamless. For a variation on this part, see my 4-hole template: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:673570

This is a template that will help you join two pieces of wood with 3/8" dowels. There are actually two templates, one with a tab on each side that will just fit over two 2x4's (ie 3 inches), and one with only a single tab, that you can use at the end of any piece of wood. Basically you clamp a guide onto each piece, and then drill through the holes with a 3/8" bit, to the depth necessary on each side to join your pieces. The holes are slightly under-sized so you will take a bit of plastic off the first time. But after that it should work well. I designed these for a bed-building project, and the fit was excellent (ie no difficultly fitting pieces together, and minimal mis-alignment). I printed on a Makerbot Replicator 2, Low quality setting, With Support, and 30% inflll (for stiffness). You could go even higher on the infill, to minimize wobble while you drill. If you want to drill-through two pieces, you can also do it with this guide, using the method from my 5-hole template: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:673565

description.text:
This is a lid that I use on my fish bowl. I made it to keep filthy little cat paws from terrorizing the fish. I guess you could use it for anything, though. It has four holes for easy lifting.  
The STL is sized so that the inside of the lid is 127mm. If you need it to be a different size, scale by desired_size/127, times 100 if your software takes a percent.  
I printed on a Replicator 2 at Medium quality, With Support. A sharp wood chisel is a great way to remove the support.  
I designed the initial shape in Fusion 360, but then did postprocessing in Meshmixer to make it smoother. I have included the pre-smoothing .mix file.

comments.text:
it was a test piece to make sure I had the dimensions and thickness right before I cut it out of metal.
Likewise the aluminum part was my first ever CNC, I didn't want to try it on steel until I had all the
procedure worked out with softer metal. I broke two endmills before I got the G-code and feed right
with the HSM-CNC post-processor for Inventor and Tormach mill. The steel cut in one pass, nice and clean.
The 3D printer is good for making test parts before I commit to CNC in metal.

description.text:
This is a parameterized Solidworks 2014 file for a parts bin organizer.  This can be made from cardboard, matte board or many other materials.  Enter your desired length, width, height, and material thickness and you can create a custom DXF file for a laser cutter.  
DXF files for 3 sizes of cardboard boxes are shown.

Update 3/23/2015: updated the SolidWorks file (SolidWorks 2015 SP0) and added a zip version of the file. In the SolidWorks file, enter your length, width, and height into the equation editor variables. Enter the material thickness into the base flange properties. Then just flatten the part and create a DXF for your laser cutter. One laser cutter shop in my area has a 18x32" size limit. This will fit boxes:
7"(L) x 5"(W) x 3.5"(H),
6.5"(L) x 5"(W) x 5"(H), and
9.25"(L) x 8.5"(W) x 3.5"(H) for example Minimum width is 2.25" (no error checking is done)
Minimum depth is 4" The parts and DXF files include small dots that mark the fold lines. I cut the parts with the cardboard corrugation running vertical on the box sides. Folding the back tab into the small slot is tricky so be sure to fold the box as close as possible to the right lines.

comments.author: relet

comments.text: intuitive i felt that a double Chebyshev would preform good enought even with low precision parts, a double or triple sarrus might do that to but in a Chebyshev  all rotational joints are coplanar and i felt that it were simpler to construct at low precision as its function less depends on the joints ability to withstand sideways momentum. A sarrus links linearity is derived from the perpendicular stiffness of rotational joints there for stability and linearity depend directly on sideways joint precision, in a Chebyshev linearity is derived from the relative length of the linkage. sideways stability could be increased with further cross bracing.
comments.author: relet

This is a vase I designed with respect to symmetric forms used in Persian carpets. I am going to design and upload more vases of this set in future.
There are two STL files available, one is a small vase proper for an office desk to use as a pen holder or a pot for small plants, and the other file titled as huge, is a normal vase big enough to hold some roses. !!!Please read Instructions for slicer configurations!!!

!! IMPORTANT !!
This should be printed as a "Vase" in slicer configurations. the model itself is a full filled solid mass which will NOT provide you an empty vase when it's been printed normally.
If you use Repetier host, Cura engine has a ready to use vase option.
If you use Cura, there is an option called "black magic", which is an ugly name for this spiral vase type of continuous extrusion printing with only one layer of outer surface.

author: gida38

description.text:
This is a remix of the original model by lordmundi. The original model had been imported into sketchup, and had a bunch of stl errors as a result. I cleaned it up, slightly changed all the dimensions, and changed the mounting for the arduino to use M2.5 bolts. You can optionally insert nuts from the bottom to screw the bolts into, but they will hold into the plastic on their own. Watch my review and build-log of the Shapeoko2, here:
http://www.jeremyblum.com/2015/04/26/shapeoko2/ This is designed to mount the Arduino on the Shapeoko 2 for Wiring method 3: http://docs.shapeoko.com/wiring_3.html

Print the part.
Screw the Arduino in using M2.5 Bolts and options nuts.
Attach the part to the right Y axis mounting plating using M3 bolts and nuts.

title: 3D Printed Chinese Oriental Folding Fan (No Assembly Required)

description.text: As Chinese New Year is nearing soon, furthermore in regards to this year as its the Lunar Year Of The Goat, I've designed an oriental Chinese folding fan collection for decorative and practical usage. The Chinese calligraphy on the (Wood & Gold) fan refers to the word 'GOAT' in Mandarin. The Red fan calligraphy describes a prosperous and fortune abundance during this Year Of The Goat. The 1st visual which the model is holding refers to the fan printed in WOOD PLA material, 2nd visual fan is printed in GOLD PLA material and the RED fan is printed with RED PLA material (embossed with Chinese calligraphy and Goat pattern). I've decided to upload the RED fan to share with everyone who's interested in printing it (it's also in www.instructables.com ) . As for the other 2 fan designs, the STL files can be purchased in www.cgtrader.com (http://www.cgtrader.com/3d-print-models/art/other/3d-printed-chinese-oriental-folding-fan-in-gold-filament and http://www.cgtrader.com/3d-print-models/art/other/3d-printed-chinese-oriental-folding-fan ). For those who would wish to purchase the 3D printed models, please do contact me for further arrangement.
*Important note: All filament type usage varies, so if the fan is very loose, just use fishing tackle line (5 pounder line) should be sufficient to tie the fan ribs together.

title: Rose with Stem & Thorns & Sepals & Hip for Valentine's Day

description.text:
I wanted a more complete Rose, so I took a basic rose and added stuff :)  Both open and closed versions.  Thorns can be a single color, 2 color glued, or dual extruder.  
Added vase mostly stolen from Microsoft's Rose (I like this rose better though).  Fixed smallish pin holes on stem.  
Please support my projects!

If you want to support my projects, check out and share my completely unrelated, yet still cool, Working Lego R2-D2 YouTube channel at http://www.youtube.com/MyL3G0 - I make a few pennies off the ads.
Rose with Thorns & Stem & Bits

I didn't modify the rose, but everything else is brand new from scratch.  
Printing:

I printed everything at .2mm layer height with no supports or raft, 10% infill (though not much actually uses infill, you could probably get away with less). Supports are built-in to the sepal models where needed.
  • Print the open &/or closed roses
  • For each rose, print a set of the sepals (leafy looking things), snap off the supports and center supports when done. The center is a bit tricky, I could probably do better, but wanted to post this for folks...
    • There's a version of the sepals without supports which works better for some slicers
    • There's now a version with fatter supports which might be needed for other slicers.
  • For each rose, print a stem, here it gets tricky
    • Easiest is just to print the 1 color stem
    • There's also a stem with holes for the thorns so you can print them in different colors, unfortunately they don't fit well, so expect some work
    • There's also a dual-extruder thorn version, which seems to work better, but uses a lot of filament for the effect (because of the tall walls)
  • For each rose, print a pin (or use 3mm filament sections). The original rose was designed for 3mm filament, but you may have to either shrink the pin or file the holes a tiny bit. Alternatively, just glue them together.
    • Assembly:

If you built separate stem & thorns, glue the thorns to the stem, probably needs a little filing, good luck!  
Put the pin in the rose, attach the sepals, and then attach the stem.  Test it first, you may need to file the holes.  
Please support my projects!

If you want to support my projects, check out and share my completely unrelated, yet still cool, Working Lego R2-D2 YouTube channel at http://www.youtube.com/MyL3G0 - I make a few pennies off the ads.

comments.text:
WoW! These are beautiful. You did a great job with it and only one MAJOR problem is I'm now sick and tired of printing them. :)
EVERYBODY that sees them wants a dozen (or half dozen) plus a gold vase. For folks that have never seen a 3D printed piece they are just awed at the roses. My CR-10 printer does a great job printing them and these dang things are going to wear it out before the warrantee is over. I've decided to hide them from where I had some on my sit-down kitchen counter so folks don't see them. I must have printed at least 75 of them of all colors. The bright yellow filament from Hatchbox make beautiful yellow roses and are my favorite. Somehow missed the pins until today and have been using center-cut toothpicks and CA glue.
Much Thanks,
Jerry in NW Florida

comments.text: I just assumed you were using solid fill. When I made the originals, my first thought was that solid loops would be stronger, but that's not the case since the flexing forces will concentrate along just a few of those solid layers that are situated at the crests. The semi-fill internal matrix makes the loops behave more like bone.

remixed_from.title: Enclosure for the Raspberry Pi Model B+

description.text:
Laser cut Raspberry Pi case (with layers). Works with :
  • Raspberry Pi (model B+)
  • Raspberry Pi 2 (a model B)
    • This is a modification of the http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:545709 case which is designed by http://crispconcept.com/. It is inspired from PiBow but not a derivative. The logo is the official Raspberry logo and the cuts and engravings are ordered to prevent the acrylic to bend during cut as much as possible.

Must be cut in 3mm thick acrylic layers... The top one must be transparent to see the engravings.  
Assemble with 4x3mm screws.

description.text:
Radius : 6mm
Hole : 8mm x 12mm
with cable slot mini 02
Radius : 11mm
Hole : 12mm x 15mm
with cable slot
Rocket

Dual rocking extruder for Prusa i3.
Direct extrusion with a single stepper motor.
Basculating heads prevent inactive nozzle to interfere with the part already printed avoiding contamination.
Anti-oozing system.
Reduced mass allow direct extrusion. 09/05/2016
In order to make the project more "readable" I tried to simplify and put in some order.
i) Eliminated the 3mm version (too hard to make it working!)
ii) Added 0.5mm clearance from heatsink to backplate, so modified Idlers, Idlers_pivot and Pendulum.
iii) Modified Idlers to avoid mutual interference and Servo_Cam interference
iv) Modified the fan duct (print fan) for a more efficient cooling
v) Added "mouse ears" to Pendulum and BackPlate to improove adesion and make prints easier ( if you don't want them you can do a "Divide ojects" and remove). 24/03/2016
Dual Dondolo on CoreGF: automatic head change
https://youtu.be/E3vc4A_5x28 05/12/2015
Published the "DONDOLO v1 Assembly Guide rev_10.pdf" to help during the assembly procedure.
Published the "PTFE Cutting Tool" to help cutting the PTFE tube in the proper way. 13/10/2015
Added a driving wheel spacer fo use with E3D MK8 type driving wheel. Insert the driving wheel in reverted position, ( the grub screw outside ). Firmware configuration tool available at: http://marlinkimbra.it/
thanks to MagoKimbra (Alberto Cotronei).
No more need to manually adapt the fw, you can configure and dowload an advanced version of Marlin supporting Dondolo (among other interesting multicolor extruders like "4 Way Flux Capacitor":
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:498922) BOM in the instructions. Note: the Cam _Pendulum is the part you have to "tune" depending on your filament diameter and drive gear effective diameter. Here is for 3mm filament and a 7mm drive gear (made hobbing a 8mm round bar). 19/May/2015
Is ready the version for E3D v6 1.75mm filament hotends:
Pendulum_E3Dv6_175.stl
Cam_Pendulum_175.stl
Tested Mk8 E3D drive gear,... very good drive gear, I strongly reccomend it.
Also added a "front bar" to increase the stiffness of assembly. Thank you. :-) First test:
http://youtu.be/gPh625bMtUg
Anti-oozing test:
http://youtu.be/gTiOnj0SXrU Change Log:
Ver. 1.02
Changed the hotend dual fan duct from 25mm to 30mm (4 CFM) Ver. 1.01r
updated Cam Pendulum (Cam_Pendulum_101r.stl) the older was'nt enough to keep the clearance of the inactive filament from drive gear (for 3mm filament). Ver. 1.01
minor changes on :
pendulum to increase stiffness and
idlers and pendulum cam to increase pression from spring to filament and stability on bistable system.

Print preferably in PETG, more elastic and durable material than ABS and easier to print.
Layer 0.2, T 240°C, bed 50°C, speed 45-60mm/s.
Follow "DONDOLO v1 Assembly Guide rev_10.pdf". Soon a wiring diagram. DONDOLO v1.0b bill of materials. Screws and nuts 2 3.5mm washer
22 M3 nuts
4 M3 x 8mm countersunk socket screw (Motor)
2 M3 x 6mm socket head cap screw (Anti-oozing thin plates)
3 M3 x 8mm socket head cap screw (1 Servo Cam + 2 Prints Fan Duct Support )
6 M3 x 10mm socket head cap screw (3 Double Clamp + 2 Idler Pivot + 1 BackPlate)
4 M3 x 12mm socket head cap screw (Servo)
6 M3 x 16mm socket head cap screw (2 Cam Pend. + 2 Backplate + 2 Prints Fan)
4 M3 x 25mm socket head cap screw (2 Front Bar + 2 Prints Fan)
2 M3 x 15mm Spacer (X Carriage - Prints Fan Duct Support) Mechanical parts 1 E3D MK8 Filament drive gear
1 F 695ZZ ball bearing
2 604ZZ ball bearings
1 6mm x 52mm x 1mm traction spring Electrical parts 1 standard servo (metal gears MG995)
1 NEMA 17 stepper motor 42BYGHW208 (or 17HS13-0404S) 0,4A 30ohm 37mH
1 5v DC-DC converter
1 40mm fan Plastic printed parts (0,6EU cm^3) 1 Backplate
1 Pendulum
1 Pendulum Cam
1 Idler sx
1 Idler dx
1 Idler pivot sx
1 Idler pivot dx
1 Double hotend clamp
1 Double hotend fan duct
1 Servo Cam
1 Front bar
1 Prusa i3 X Carriage modified
1 Prints Fan Duct
1 Prints Fan Duct Support
1 Driving Wheel Spacer Custom parts 1 anti-oozing sx 0.5mm thin plate
1 anti-oozing dx 0.5mm thin plate
2 M4 x 7mm threaded rod Hotends 2 E3D v6 (or E3D Lite) Full Kit Note:
the Cam _Pendulum is the part you have to "tune" depending on your filament diameter and drive gear effective diameter. Th recomended choice is the 1.75mm version with E3D Lite Hotends and E3D drive gear.

comments.text:
Hi Irobri,
altough every print in the examples gallery was printed with the (original) 3mm version this is more tricky than the 1.75mm.
You need a stepper driver with a current-decay adjustable and\or higher microstepping capabilities (G3D, RAPS128) otherwise you will see some artefacts mainly caused by the lower step rate. The lower step rate also increase the heating of the motor so you have to fine adjust the max current to avoid overheating and, on the other side, to have enough torque (more than in the case of 1.75mm filament) to drive the filament.
Anyway I added a compressed file (3mm_version_parts.rar). ...:-)
comments.author: irobri

comments.text: Hi Gianni,
comments.author: Gianni3D

comments.text:
I used G3D driver (only for the extruder motor). I have not tested the 8825 with 3mm filament in Dondolo to say they don't work, I tested the 8825 with 1.75mm, 24v power supply, motor 17HS16-0284S and I can say that RAPS128 is better.
What I wanted to explain is that the 3mm version is harder to make it working.
The artfacts I speaking of are such that are visible only in GOOD CLEAN prints (the most of people never saw them!). My motors never heat over 40°C even if they print continuosly for 27 hours (and 200 hours in 9 days http://www.thingiverse.com/make:214269), many people often put a fan on the back of the extruder stepper (I call this "being stupid").
This project has more than 300 "I like it" ( not many indeed ) but only 7 "I made it", in my opinion it means that is not so easy as it appear. It's not for beginners.

comments.text:
Ormai si leggono più cazzate che cose serie. A scrivere non ci vuole molto. Io faccio così: ondivido la mia esperienza e la supporto con i fatti senza aver la presunzione o la volontà di convincere nessuno. A ciascuno la sua valutazione. L' ABS non lo considero nemmeno per questo tipo di impiego sia come caratteristiche meccaniche che come facilità di stampa lo ritengo inferiore al PETG, l' elasticità è una caratteristica positiva, a mio vedere, ed una maggiore rigidità può essere ottenuta aumentando lo spessore dei perimetri e dell' infill. Il nylon è meccanicamente adeguato ma MOOOLTO più difficile da stampare e con stabilità termica dimensionale nettamente inferiore il che si traduce in minore precisione e tolleranze di realizzazione più grandi con conseguente aumento delle criticità nella realizzazione del sistema.
Spero di essere stato sufficientemente chiaro e di una qualche utilità. .... :-D

comments.text:
Hi,
altough the 3mm version was the first I made (and almost all the prints in the pics gallery of this project are printed with the 3mm version!) it is also harder to make it working. The 3mm filament need a stronger traction spring (shorter spring) and a higher torque. Being the first version, every part that is not explicitly marked "175" is intended for 3mm version. The driving wheel is MK8 for both, GOOD QUALITY Mk8, with sharp theeth!... I found E3D are very good altough more expensive.
The parameters you are asking for are machine depending. If you make the "Hephestos Upgrade Kit" I can give you the fw already configured and the profiles for Cura and Simplify3D for others you have to do it yourself. When you have a system "almost" working please contact me and I help you to make it, at least, "good" working. ... :-)

comments.text:
Hi,
the spring (one) dont' have to be so tight if the teeth drive are sharp enougheven if 3mm filament need more force respect to 1.75mm. The drive gear must be positioned with the hobbed part centered respect to the filament duct on the pendulum. Depend on the dimensions of the dive (MK8) may be better in reverse position with a spacer. I use a retracion length of 6mm.
For the insertion of servo cam you have to put the servo in the middle position of the full ragge (65°) the inserting the cam pointing towards the motor shaft. In both end-positions the cam must be perpendicular to the surfaces of the pendulum it is pushing. Fine adjust the end-positions (default 10, 120) to satisfy this condition.

comments.text: Hi, is it also possible to connect the servo direct to the ramp board without using an external dcdc power supply?
comments.author: Tolstoii

comments.text: Hi, the servo connectors of RAMPS board are for low power servos, for this design I use a high torque metal gears servo. Altough the servo is active just during the switch between the hotends and the power consumption is very low, during the switching (and for a fraction of a second) can absorbe up to 2A of current. The 5v regulator on the board is capable of 500mA. The cost of a DC-DC switching regulator is about 2EU.

I printed Ninjaflex (shore hardness A85, Filaflex is A82), 1.75mm :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:856101
The path is not very short but the PTFE tube of the hotend is very close to the driving wheel and cutted it to fit both the pinch roller ball bearing and the driving wheel itself, no space left for the filament to run out.

I tested both E3D v6 and E3D Lite hotends with success.

comments.text: And else one question. Have you any problem with servo trembling? I have bed autoleveling and sometimes there is a big problem.
comments.author: andy_111

comments.text:
The mechanism is self-stabilizing in extreme positions. The servo only switch from one to the other and then is disabled. This ensure a long life for the servo, low power consumption, absence of trembling due to servo instability and first of all PRECISION, because this not depends on servo precision.
Anyone who pretends to use a RC servo for precise positioning really don't know how a RC servo works!..:-)

comments.text: The number on the pendulum cam indicates the distance of the upper corners from the motor shaft axys. The greater the filament diameter the greater the number. The reason why they are strange numbers (13.92 instead of 14, or 16.08 instead of 16?) is that they are indirect parameters.

comments.text:
The wiring strictly depend on the board model. Any board capable of driving two hotends can succesfully wired. Depending on the driving capabilities of the DC-DC converter on your board you may need an external DC-DC to supply the 5v to the servo (3-4EU), if you have an heated bed and a RAMPS board you also need an external mosfet driver (3EU).
There are a large variety of possibilities and configurations. .... :-)

comments.text:
Hi WFB,
no problems in getting the hotend nozzles at the same height. Just slightly loose the 3 screws of the hotend clamp, put the bed in touch with one tip nozzle, switch to the other hotend and adjust to put bed in touch with this too. Tighten the screw and check the alignment. The alignment of nozzles is not so critical as in fixed hotends. 0.1mm of misalignment have no serious effects on print quality. No auto bed levelling is used.
Ciao!..:-)

title: Model of a worm drive gearing

description.text:
A printable model of the two main components of a worm drive.
With a little stand indicating the gear ratio. For the best results, the worm shaft is printed in halves and then glued together.

Printed in PLA on a Reprappro Mendel (single colour) with a 0.5 mm nozzle and 0.3 mm layer height.  
No support material needed, since the worm shaft is split in half and glued together with glue (used for building model airplanes, etc.)

comments.text: Hi, this is what i've looked for. How did you drow it? Everyone i've asked knows the math and how to make one, but not how to draw one in CAD. I'm using SolidWorks and the gear is imposible to draw.
comments.author: StoneAgeSkillz

comments.text:
Hi, I used Autodesk Inventor to create this geometry (there is a worm-drive tool) but I guess you can create it with standard-tricks as well; The grooves in the gear are made out of trapezoidal rotation cut-outs with the rotation axis tilted in the right manner so it fits with the calculated angles you need to mesh the gears properly. Then you copy it around.
More is difficult to explain in a Thingiverse-comment, so I guess for the rest, you have to bend your brain around on your own... Please note that the trapezoidal rotation cut-outs are just valid in this case for this particular geometry chosen for the worm. (There are many, many other worm geometries...)

title: Filamentreinigungsschraube 3/8" (Filament Screw) für Prusa i3 Hephestos und ähnliche

description.text:
In die Schraube wird ein kleines Stück Schwamm gesteckt. Dann wird der obere Teil verschlossen und das Filament kann durch die Schraube geführt werden.
Der Schwamm hält Staub und andere Verunreinigungen vom
Extruder fern. Man kann sich mehrere Schrauben ausdrucken, so kann die Schraube auch beim Verwahren des Filamentes an der Rolle bleiben. Ich nutze nur 1.75mm Filament. Daher ist die 3mm Version nicht getestet. Vielleicht ist jemand so nett und gibt Rückmeldung ob die Schraube ok ist. Tipps:
Nicht zu viel Schwamm verwenden, sonst geht das Filament zu
schwergängig hindurch.
Knickt das Schwammstückchen einmal in der Länge und nutzt eine Pinzette zum platzieren in der Schraube. Siehe Fotos.
Die Schrauben nur Handfest anziehen!
.100 or .200 Layer are both fine. Printed at 50mm/s

author: krow333

title: Clash of Clans Gem Box and Gem

description.text:
Hello, Thank you for your interest! Firstly, I'd like to say that I'm no artist, so it's not perfect. It was modelled from the picture in game. I decided to make this for my girlfriend as a present. When I searched first to see if anybody had already done this, I couldn't find any. I saw a few people also requesting this, so I've uploaded it for them.
I may upload a revision with a hinge system to allow the lid to move. I printed this on a printrbot simple metal with PLA. Settings were 0.1mm resolution, and pretty much solid for strength. Total print time was around 18 hours including around 40 gems for show! Please enjoy this,
and thank you for your time.

I used the recommended standard settings for the printrbot simple metal that are listed on their website. The only thing I did was slow down the entire print process with an 80% factor in repetier. Warning: The gem was scaled down to about 0.5 in each axis to better reflect what size I believe they are. You can print them in many different sizes as the images of gems are all in different sizes to reflect the natural and random likeness of them. So you could, and should do the same. Once printed, you could glue the lid in place, as I did. Or you could design your own hinge type system to have a functional chest. I decided I didn't need it. Some tips for printing, that I found useful:
With the box, I printed it 'top' side down. So that it goes largest cross sectional area to smallest. This helped reduce the support material required. However, it's really up to you. The lid I printed upside down also, I just felt it would be easier to tear the support off the outside than from the 'inside' of the lid. The final step is to let me know how it goes and have fun.

author: tovarna

description.text:
I am quite fascinated by multicopters, expecially tricopters. But as well there is a great populatiry in Europe about LEGO. And I always wondered, why there are only a few LEGO frames for multicopter use. The answer: There are no special bricks or motor mounts for LEGO.
Therefore I made my own. Working professionally for a company to mesh parts for cars, I used several lunch breaks to design my own bricks using several drafts and models appearing in the world wide web.
Now I want to present them to the community.
They are high detailed because I wanted to get the best resolution.

The design for the non moving motor mounts can be used by all kinds of multicopters, such as quadro, hexas and so on. Within the file "arms.stl" you wil find a pair of motor mounts using LEGO bricks as frame. Use zip-ties for attaching it properly - or glue. The tilt mechanism was a little more difficult. I made two versions of it. Version 1: The first version is a special brick used to attach the tilting mechanism. Because I wanted to create a good turning response on the mechanism, the whole movable part is using ball bearings on a 3mm tube. The link for the bearings you can find below. Version 2: In this version I used "normal" bricks from LEGO technic with an adaptor for the 3mm tube. The "normal" bricks are attached (with zip-ties or glue) on a usual LEGO plate. This is even more stiff than version 1. After creating and priniting these parts I did not have any more time to finish the project. My experience is the following:
Be careful when you insert the bearings to the tilt mechanism. The diameter was too precise. Because of the printing process the diameter of the original part was too small. In the files I attached to this project, the diameter was already changed !!! For printing a tricopter you can use following files:
Lego_tri_1_complete.stl = LTM_arms.stl + LTM_brick.stl + LTM_rotate.stl or Lego_tri_2_complete.stl = LTM_arms.stl + LTM_rotate.stl + LTM_huelse_einzeln.stl + LTM_huelse_einzeln.stl

I used the following ballbearings:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/10-Stueck-Nadelhuelse-Nadellager-Nadelbuechse-Bearings-HK0206-HK0910-HK-Series-/161169219086
It is the KH0306 which is 3x6.5x6mm

remixed_from.author: benipk
remixed_from.title: Excel spreadsheet to determine workable T-O-M feed rates

description.text:
I'm the kind to mess with W/T parameters, not feedrate or flowrate. I don't know why, maybe because I like the standard 30mm/s speed and can't break away from old-style sounds and printing. So I just mess with W/T until it's perfect... Until now. I'm sick of all them stupid calibration cubes. My mom is amused at the number of ubiquitous calibration cubes I have made.
So I made this program that takes values and spits out w/t values. It's windows only because it's written in C++. The source is packed inside the Zip folder.
Color coded by category and to make it all colorful to remind you that Skeinforge is your friend. 
The calculations are based off of the thing that this is a derivative of.

Install: Place EXE file somewhere on computer.
Uninstall: Nuke EXE file.
Run: Open EXE file. Use: Enter your system parameters and chosen Layer Height and Feedrate values. Click "Calculate" to make W/T number. If it seems strange, please let me know so I can try to correct the equations. If it makes your printer put down too much plastic, try increasing the W/T Fudge Factor. If it puts down too little, lower that parameter. This will end up being your "manual calibration" factor since reality will always be a bit different. This is what you'll be playing with if you want nice infill. It'll probably be higher for lower layer heights were excess plastic is not tolerated.

The Pi Tank is the first open source 3D printable Raspberry Pi based robot with a Kinect sensor that you can control with your smartphone. The purpose of this project is to create a robot that anyone could build. The robot can act as an artificial pet and anyone can write software for it (preferably on mobile platforms so that the distribution would be the easiest). The first version was created by Kristjan Järvan, Madis Kaasik, Ulf Anso and Ilya Kuzovkin in Garage48 event 08.02.2015. The design stl files are downloadable at Thingiverse and the Raspberry image from GitHub. There will be a better initial mobile app for it – we want it to work just like Parrot AR drone interface (camera on the background and buttons on top). And yes – it has a laser. Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/opensourcetank?fref=ts
Github (code): https://github.com/kuz/Garage48-PiTank
Connection instructions: http://www.madiskaasik.com/connection-instructions.html Sources for some 3D prited designs are from Drogerdy - Raspberry Pi Controlled Tank Bot by timmiclark: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:652851 Kinect mount source is Kinect mount to camera tripod by Henkka: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5601

This is the RCD-1. It's my first attempt at designing a quad. It uses the rugged arms from the MHQ Hovership (with permission) and sports front and rear bumpers on the bottom plate to mount LED's. UPDATE:
I am currently testing MK2 prototype so have removed all previous files for now. The MK2 contains numerous design changes to most parts. CREDITS: I would just like to say thank you to Hovership who have allowed me the use of their arms. PS: If you make one, let me know! Any feed back is greatly received. Current Version: V0.8 Coming Soon! Previous:
V0.72
  • 8 & 35mm standoffs
  • Angled board cam mount
  • Angled Mobius mount.
    v0.71
  • New middle plate incorporates holes for bobbins anti-vibe FC plate
  • New anti-vibe FC mount
  • New FC mount can be used on other frames using 2 plates
    v0.7
  • Board Cam supports up to 30x30 board cams. There are no mounting holes so you will need to drill your ow (carefully!).
    v0.6.7
    -Top plate complete
    -Tweaks and more tweaks
    v0.6.6
  • Middle plate complete
    v0.6.5
  • Bottom plate complete
  • Mounting holes enlarged to M3
  • Corrected PDB mounting hole spacing
    v0.6
  • Modified front end to adjust for rugged MHQ Hovership arms
  • Modified Mobius top plate. Still a WIP
  • Board cam mount to do.
    v0.4a
  • Front end redesign due incorrect geometry.
    v0.4
  • Initial design finished.
    v0.3b
  • Initial Design.
    • Future Milestones:
    0.7x - First prototype complete and released for testing
    0.8 - 0.9 - Last minute changes.
    1.0 - Full release.

2-3 shells
80% Infill

FC: 36x36 FC of your choice.

Battery: 3-4S 1000-1500mah (around 80-90mm long max) 4 x M3 6mm Screw + 8 nuts to mount PDB

Please check out http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:305204 as it is an updated version. Loki's Chitauri Scepter from The Avengers (2012)

This a replica of the short staff Loki used to mind control Hawkeye and several others, and escape from the S.H.I.E.L.D. compound. This item is approximately 96 cm long (36 in). Notice: This device will not grant you the ability to fire energy blasts or take over the minds of your enemies. Such upgrades are welcome as derivatives. Notice 2: This thing is undergoing a redesign. Faults were found during construction and after some use.

• Print
  • Assemble (not the heroes)
  • ???
  • Take over the world
    • I printed the staff with ABS, 2 shells, 0.2 layer height, and 10% infill. Some pieces do require support. Included is the staff sliced to fit a Makerbot Replicator in .stl files (may not be oriented for minimal support). If you need to slice it differently, I've also included the .skp file with the original designs in it. All names referenced below should match the .stl file names. Note: Pieces have small holes for short segments of ~1.7mm filament. These are used for test fitting and alignment for gluing. If you do not own a 3d printer, the design files should allow you to make your own scepter out of wood or other carvable material. Much of the process after cutting out the segments will be the same.

remixed_from.author: MakerBlock
remixed_from.title: Cupcake Autohoming GCode for Unicorn Tray

title: Unicorn Autohoming GCode for Cupcake with Sticky Tray

description.text:
This is a simplified and more refined version of my prior Unicorn autohoming code.
  • I discovered that simple autohoming was good - but that if you don't raise the Z stage before the XY autohome, you can accidentally draw a line on the sticky note.
  • I also discovered that bringing the XY stage to the center without having raised the Z stage could run the pen into several sheets of the sticky note. The sticky note pads I'm using aren't the freshest and the bottom ends of the pad are a little raised.
  • Raising and lowering the Z stage helps tremendously with avoiding accidental lines on the pad as well as with avoiding knocking into the pad as the stage returns center.
  • I've recently discovered a reasonable use for the "end.txt" file when using a Unicorn. At the conclusion of a print job, the Z stage will be raised 10mm and the tray brought to the front for easy removal of the top sticky note.

• Use the attached GCode in your Cupcake with XY minimum endstops installed and with the Sticky Note Tray for Unicorn printing ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6720 )
  • Copy and paste your desired Unicorn printing code between the section marked start and the section marked end. Your Cupcake will now auto home, print, and then bring the tray full forward for 10 seconds for removal of the sticky note.

EDIT 10/31/2016
This headphones project is now called the EQ-1, as our first Certified Open Source Hardware product. We will eventually be working on such improvements as:

Bluetooth wireless connectivity
Foam pads replaced with printed version, in a flexible filament

The Duli 2.0 is finally here! This new design allows for maximum adjustability and comfort. Check out our build video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLu25lZJQX0 Print out and enjoy your favorite music, in the future! These headphones are available fully assembled via our Etsy: http://etsy.me/1Bjy0fE

You'll need the following parts printed out to make these headphones: headband_bottom_geared.stl x2
duli_cup.stl x2
duli_cap.stl x2
top_gear.stl x1
headband_top.stl x1
top_gear_pin.stl x1
pin1.stl x4
pin2.stl x2 Non-printed components: (available as a kit via tindie)
Speakers x2
Foam pads x2
Speaker Jack x2
22 AWG wire
1/4" Audio Cable Solder the speaker jack to the speaker, using a short length of 22 AWG wire. Snap the speaker into the duli_cup, and tighten the nut to attach the jack to the duli_cup. Slide the foam pad over duli_cap, and then attach to duli_cup using two copies of pin1. Insert both headband_bottom_geared into headband_top. Once inserted fully, attach top_gear and top_gear_pin. Attach the duli_cup to the headband_bottom_geared using pin2. That's it!

This Thing is an Inkscape template for printing on a bandaid. The bandaid I used just barely fit onto my Sticky Note Tray, but I needed to keep it clipped down with binder clips. The dimensions of the bandaid were a 19mm x 65mm wide area with two small curved areas at the edge, making the entire bandaid 79mm long. Custom bandaids for all! As with the 100 acre wood sticky note GCode ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6729 ), this is based on the now public domain original Winnie The Pooh drawings.

• Print the Sticky Note Tray, insert magnets
  • Add bandaid
  • Add two small binder clips, pinch and twist the handles to remove them
  • Print (hopefully using the autohoming code!)
  • Adorn thyself!

number_of_teeth_on_planets = 6 Bottom layer 'fused' a little together. Flexing the thing broke it loose. Printed with Normal Quality - layer thickness 0.1mm with ABS. First ABS print on this printer had a little flow trouble and tweaked it on the fly.

Put your Arduino in an Altoids case. This has blocks that hold the PCB and can be "melted" with a soldering iron or similar to keep the PCB in place. Also, there are 2mm holes that can be drilled out to your preference to use screws to hold the Arduino in place.   There is 3 mm of space under the PCB, ample room for wires and leads underneath.
Access for USB programming, power, or other connections will necessitate holes through the Altoids tin, but I leave that as an exercise for you, gentle maker.

Printed with 3 perimeters and 50% infill. There is not a whole lot of infill, given the thickness of the part, but a little in the mounting pads.  Let it fully cool for maximum flatness before prying it from the printing bed.

title: Convex hull of two circle roller

description.text:
The two circle roller is that circular discs (diameter R) are interlocked perpendicularly to each other so that the distance of the center of the discs is R times the square root of 2. This object has a peculiar property that its height of the gravity center is always constant for any attitude of the object. The convex hull of the two circle roller has also the same property.
The shape of this object is very similar to the Oloid roller, however, it is essentially different.
Please use milling machine. If you do not have any milling machine or 3D printer, please assemble a paper-craft of this object.
